bioghist.p: Founded in 1743 by Benjamin Franklin, the American Philosophical Society was the first learned society in the United States. For over 250 years, the Society has played an important role in American cultural and intellectual life. Until the mid-nineteenth century, the Society fulfilled the role of a national academy of science, national library and museum, and even patent office. Early members of the Society included Thomas Jefferson, David Rittenhouse, Benjamin Rush, Stephen Peter Du Ponceau, George Washington, and many other figures prominent in American history.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of financial records of the American Philosophical Society. The bulk of the collection consists of "warrants" listing payees and amounts for expenditures from 1938 to 1992 and supporting documents including receipts. The collection also includes a check register and general ledger from the 1980s, a small batch of "worthless securities" and related correspondence, tax information for employees and quarterly tax returns from 1986-1987, and cash books covering the period from 1932 to 1941.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
